questions.text: A 24-year-old presented with swelling in the wrist joint. Histopathological examination of the swelling revealed spindle cells with palisading of the nuclei and Verocay bodies. Which of the following is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schwannoma

 

The histopathological examination is suggestive of schwannoma.

 

Schwannomas are well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses that surround but do not invade the associated nerve. They are frequently associated with NF2 gene inactivating mutations on chromosome 22g12.

 

The tumor is composed of fibrocellular bundles that form a whorled pattern under the microscope. There are dense and compact cellular areas (Antoni A pattern) that alternate with loose acellular areas (Antoni B pattern). Antoni A pattern areas have palisaded nuclei known as Verocay bodies. Nerve fibres are typically found stretched across the capsule but not within the tumor. Hemosiderin and lipid-laden macrophages are found in degeneration areas.

 

Schwann cells characteristically express S-100 protein.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurofibroma: Neurofibromas are also benign nerve sheath tumors but differ histologically. They are not encapsulated and involve the nerve itself. They do not show the distinct Antoni A and B patterns or Verocay bodies seen in schwannomas.

 

Option C. Neuroma: Neuromas are non-neoplastic proliferations of nerve tissue, often occurring after nerve injury. They lack the distinctive histopathological features of spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies.

 

Option D. Glioma: Gliomas are primary tumors of the central nervous system originating from glial cells. They do not present with the histopathological features described and are not typically found in peripheral locations like the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Schwannomas are characterized by spindle cells with palisading nuclei and Verocay bodies, forming well-circumscribed, encapsulated masses. These features, along with S-100 protein expression, distinguish schwannomas from other types of nerve sheath tumors and central nervous system tumors.

questions.text: Nugent score is for diagnosis of? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis


The Nugent score is a microbiological scoring system used for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis (BV). It is based on the examination of a vaginal smear under a microscope to evaluate the presence and quantity of bacterial morphotypes, particularly Lactobacilli, Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus. A high Nugent score indicates a decrease in normal Lactobacilli and an increase in pathogenic bacteria, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis. This scoring system provides a more objective and standardized diagnosis compared to clinical criteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichomoniasis:  is incorrect because trichomoniasis is diagnosed through wet mount microscopy, culture, or molecular tests, which detect Trichomonas vaginalis, not by the Nugent score.

 

Option C. Candidiasis : is incorrect as it refers to yeast infections typically diagnosed by identifying Candida species on wet mount, KOH preparation, or fungal cultures, not using the Nugent score.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: is incorrect since Chlamydia is diagnosed through nucleic acid amplification tests (NAATs), culture, or antigen detection, not by the Nugent scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Nugent score is used for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis. It is a microbiological scoring system where the vaginal smear is analyzed for the number of lactobacilli and abnormal bacteria. The clinical scoring system for bacterial vaginosis is the Amsel's criteria, which includes the whiff test, clue cells, alkaline pH, and whitish discharge.

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Infection

 

  • The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme (EMF)
  • Most common cause – Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Erythema multiforme:

 

  • Self-limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from Type IV cell-mediated hypersensitivity.
  • It most commonly occurs following an infection with Herpes simplex virus infection.

 

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

 

 

Location:

 

  • Palms and the trunk.
  • Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions.
  • It presents as the classic acral iris or 'Target lesions'.

 

The common triggers apart from Herpes simplex infection are:

 

  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulphonamides, rifampicin, penicillin derivatives.

 

Note: Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens Johnson syndrome (SJS) & Toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drugs: While drugs can trigger EMF, they are not as commonly implicated as infections, especially HSV.

 

Option C. Vaccination: Vaccinations can occasionally trigger EMF but are less commonly a cause compared to infections.

 

Option D. Malignancy: Although malignancies can sometimes trigger EMF, they are much less common triggers compared to infections like HSV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common trigger for erythema multiforme, particularly when target lesions are present on the palms, is infection, notably with herpes simplex virus.

 

Additional information

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4. Page no 4.11, 4.13

Question Level – Intermediate 

Question Id-7462 Unique Key-Q3225777

questions.text: A patient was given digoxin. He started having side effects like nausea and vomiting. The serum concentration of digoxin was 4 mg/dL. The plasma therapeutic range is 1 mg/dL. If the half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, how long one should wait before resuming the treatment? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 80 hours

 

To determine how long it will take for the patient's serum digoxin concentration to decrease to a therapeutic level (1 mg/dL) from 4 mg/dL, we need to consider the drug's half-life. The half-life of digoxin is 40 hours, which means that every 40 hours, the concentration of the drug in the plasma will be reduced by half.

 

  • Initial concentration: 4 mg/dL
  • Therapeutic concentration: 1 mg/dL
  • Half-life of digoxin: 40 hours

 

We can use the concept of half-lives to calculate the time needed:

 

  1. After the first half-life (40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 4 mg/dL to 2 mg/dL.
  2. After the second half-life (another 40 hours), the concentration will decrease from 2 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL.

 

Therefore, it will take 80 hours for the digoxin concentration to fall from 4 mg/dL to 1 mg/dL, which is within the therapeutic range.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient experiencing side effects from digoxin with a serum concentration of 4 mg/dL, wait 80 hours (two half-lives) for the concentration to decrease to the therapeutic range before resuming treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Thoracoscore? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Complication of Surgery

 

This is not a component of Thoracoscore. While complications of surgery can impact outcomes, they are not a predefined parameter in the Thoracoscore risk model.

 

The complication of surgery is not a component of Thoracoscore.

 

Thoracoscore is a risk model used to predict the probability of death within 30 days following thoracic surgery. The model takes into account the following nine parameters:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Performance status: This is a component of Thoracoscore. Poorer performance status is associated with a higher risk.

 

Option C. ASA grading: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The ASA score is used to assess the physical status and associated risk of patients undergoing surgery.

 

Option D. Priority of surgery: This is a component of Thoracoscore. The urgency of the surgery (elective vs. emergent) affects the risk of postoperative complications and mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thoracoscore is a predictive risk model for mortality within 30 days following thoracic surgery. It includes parameters such as age, sex, performance status, dyspnea score, ASA score, cardiovascular comorbidity, surgical procedure extent, cancer status, and urgency of surgery, but does not include the complication of surgery as a predefined parameter.

questions.text: The given chest X-ray is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tetralogy of Fallot

 

The given chest X-ray is suggestive of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The boot-shaped cardiac silhouette is seen due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that affects the structure of the heart, specifically the four major components of the heart: the pulmonary valve, the right ventricle, the ventricular septum, and the aortic valve. It is a combination of four heart defects, which are:

 

  1. Pulmonary stenosis - narrowing of the pulmonary valve, which reduces blood flow to the lungs.
  2. Ventricular septal defect - a hole in the wall that separates the right and left ventricles, which allows oxygen-poor and oxygen-rich blood to mix.
  3. Overriding aorta - the aorta is located over the ventricular septal defect, which allows blood to flow from both the left and right ventricles to the body.
  4. Right ventricular hypertrophy - thickening of the right ventricle due to increased workload, which can lead to heart failure.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial septal defect (ASD): This condition typically shows plethoric lung fields and a wide, fixed split of S2. The X-ray findings in the question do not correlate with ASD, as it does not present with a boot-shaped heart.

 

Option C. Ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSD usually shows wide, variable splitting of S2 and plethoric lung fields due to increased pulmonary blood flow. The X-ray findings described do not match VSD.

 

Option D. Ebstein's anomaly: This condition often presents with a box-shaped heart due to maternal lithium intake during pregnancy. The X-ray findings in the question do not show a box-shaped heart, thus not fitting Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is indicative of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), a congenital heart defect characterized by pulmonary stenosis, ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

choices.text: First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

questions.text: A patient presented with red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. Which of the following is more appropriately done in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) First Angiography to confirm the diagnosis

 

The patient presents with a red, tender, pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region. The term "pulsatile" suggests that the swelling has a vascular origin, likely an aneurysm or other vascular abnormality. The primary goal in managing such a swelling is to correctly identify its nature, which necessitates imaging.

 

Angiography is an imaging modality that visualizes blood vessels, helping to confirm whether the swelling is vascular, such as an aneurysm or pseudoaneurysm. This step is critical because if the swelling is indeed vascular, inappropriate interventions like incision and drainage could lead to severe complications, including hemorrhage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. First antibiotics and observation: This approach might be considered for a non-pulsatile infectious swelling, but given the vascular nature indicated by the pulsatile quality, antibiotics alone would not address the underlying vascular issue.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This procedure is appropriate for abscesses or other non-vascular swellings. Performing an incision and drainage on a vascular swelling can result in catastrophic bleeding.

 

Option D. Surgical Excision: While this might eventually be necessary, it should only be considered after confirming the diagnosis with appropriate imaging to plan the surgery safely. Blindly excising a vascular swelling without proper diagnosis can be very dangerous.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a pulsatile swelling in the inguinal region, indicative of a vascular abnormality, angiography is essential to confirm the diagnosis before deciding on the appropriate intervention.

questions.text: Sympathetic ophthalmia is a consequence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Penetrating ocular trauma

 

  • Sympathetic ophthalmia is a bilateral granulomatous panuveitis seen after a penetrating ocular trauma.
  • It can occur 2 weeks to 3 months after initial injury in 65% of cases, or following intraocular surgery.
  • The injured eye is called ‘exciting eye’ and the fellow eye is called ‘sympathising eye’.
  • The clinical picture of iridocyclitis in the sympathising eye can be divided into two stages:
  • Prodromal stage: 
    • Earliest symptoms: sensitivity to light (photophobia) and transient indistinctness of near objects.
    • Signs: retrolental flare and cells, a few keratic precipitates (KPs), mild ciliary congestion, slight tenderness of the globe, fine vitreous haze, and occasional disc oedema.
  • Fully-developed stage: 
    • Typical signs and symptoms consistent with acute plastic iridocyclitis.
    • Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and multifocal choroidal infiltrates with sub-retinal pigment epithelium (RE) infiltrates corresponding to Dalen-Fuchs nodules can be seen in the mid-periphery of the fundus.
  • Treatment includes:
    • High-dose oral prednisolone for several months.
    • Immunosuppressives such as azathioprine, cyclosporine, and methotrexate for resistant cases or as steroid-sparing agents.
    • Enucleation of a severely injured eye with no visual potential within 2 weeks of injury to prevent the occurrence of sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Differential diagnosis of Sympathetic Ophthalmia is Vogy-Koyanagi-Harada Disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blunt ocular trauma: typically does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Option C. Chemical injury: primarily affects the ocular surface and cornea rather than causing granulomatous uveitis.

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: is unrelated to ocular conditions and does not cause sympathetic ophthalmia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sympathetic ophthalmia is a preventable and treatable condition if diagnosed early and managed appropriately. Awareness of its presentation and prompt treatment can prevent severe bilateral vision loss.

questions.text: Which type of thyroid carcinoma has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid

 

Explanation: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid has the least likelihood of lymph node metastasis among the given options. Follicular carcinoma typically presents as a solitary thyroid nodule with a strong tendency for hematogenous spread rather than lymphatic spread. While it commonly metastasizes to bones (particularly thoracic vertebrae and skull) via blood vessels, lymph node involvement is rare, except in the Hurthle cell variant which may show lymph node metastases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Papillary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because papillary carcinoma has a high propensity for lymph node metastasis. It frequently spreads to Level VI (central compartment) lymph nodes, and lymph node involvement is often present even in early disease. In fact, enlarged cervical lymph nodes may be the presenting feature of papillary carcinoma in some cases.

 

Option B. Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because medullary carcinoma frequently metastasizes to lymph nodes. Involvement of lymph nodes occurs in 50-60% of cases of medullary carcinoma. This tumor, which arises from parafollicular C cells, also commonly spreads hematogenously, with the liver being the most common site of distant metastasis.

 

Option D. Anaplastic carcinoma of the thyroid - Incorrect because anaplastic carcinoma is characterized by rapid growth, extensive local invasion, and early lymph node metastasis. Being the most aggressive thyroid malignancy, it shows infiltration of surrounding structures including lymph nodes early in its course, along with distant metastases typically to the lungs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid primarily spreads hematogenously to bones rather than via lymphatics, making it unique among thyroid carcinomas in having a relatively low rate of lymph node metastasis.

choices.text: 12 hours
24 hours
6 hours

questions.text: What is the maximum duration for TRALI to occur after blood transfusion? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 6 hours

 

The maximum duration for TRALI (transfusion-related acute lung injury) to occur after blood transfusion is 6 hours.

 

TRALI is characterized as sudden onset respiratory failure that occurs during or shortly after a blood transfusion. The pathogenesis is based on a two-hit hypothesis:

 

  • Priming event - increased sequestration and sensitization of neutrophils in the lung microvasculature
  • Second knock - the factor (most commonly MHC class I antigens) present in the transfused blood product stimulates the primed neutrophils

 

Pathogenesis of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI):

 

  1. Dysregulation of Inflammatory Process: This indicates an imbalance or dysregulation in the normal inflammatory response.
  2. Leukocyte Antigen (Ag) Recipient: Refers to the recipient's leukocytes, which play a role in the immune response.
  3. Blood AB Donor: Indicates the presence of antibodies (AB) in the donated blood.
  4. First Hit: Represents an initial insult or trigger such as trauma, sepsis, or neutrophil activation that can activate the immune system.
  5. Endothelial Permeability: Describes the increased permeability of endothelial cells lining blood vessels.
  6. Second Hit: Refers to a secondary insult, which in this case is the transfusion of blood components.
  7. Transfusion Blood Components: Represents the infusion of blood products, including lysophosphatidylcholine (Lyso PC).
  8. Endothelial Activation: Activation of endothelial cells leading to cytokine release, which is the release of signalling molecules involved in immune responses.
  9. Common Pathway: Illustrates that both the first hit and the second hit converge to activate a common pathway.
  10. Alveolar Capillary Pulmonary Damage: Indicates the injury and damage occurring in the alveolar-capillary membrane in the lungs.
  11. Acute Respiratory Failure: Refers to the development of sudden respiratory distress and failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TRALI vs TACO: -

questions.text: Which of the following is the layer between the choroid and the retina? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bruch's membrane

 

Bruch's membrane is the layer situated between the choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), which is the outermost layer of the retina. It serves as a basement membrane to which the RPE is firmly adherent. This anatomical relationship is fundamental to understanding many retinal pathologies such as age-related macular degeneration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Descemet's membrane: This is incorrect as Descemet's membrane is located in the cornea, specifically between the corneal stroma and the corneal endothelium, not in the retina.

 

Option C. Photoreceptors: This is incorrect as photoreceptors (rods and cones) form the second layer of the retina, not the interface between choroid and retina. They are located within the neurosensory retina above the RPE.

 

Option D. Ganglion cell layer: This is incorrect as the ganglion cell layer is the eighth layer of the retina, containing cell bodies of ganglion cells, and is located much more internally than the choroid-retina interface.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Bruch's membrane serves as a critical boundary between the vascular choroid and the retinal pigment epithelium, playing an important role in nutrient exchange and waste removal for the outer retinal layers.

questions.text: Treatment of the male partner is needed in which of the following conditions? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Trichomoniasis

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is trichomoniasis. Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. When a female is infected with trichomoniasis, she typically presents with symptoms such as green frothy vaginal discharge.

 

Treatment of the female alone is insufficient because if her male partner is not treated, he can reinfect her. This creates a cycle where the infection is passed back and forth between partners. Therefore, treating both partners is essential to break this cycle and prevent reinfection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is not considered a sexually transmitted disease but is due to an imbalance in the vaginal microflora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Option B. Herpes genitalis: This is caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2), which produces grouped vesicles over the genitalia. The virus resides in the sacral ganglia and can reactivate under certain conditions, such as immunosuppression. The best advice for couples during active lesions is abstinence from sexual intercourse, but partner treatment is not typically necessary.

 

 

Option C. Candidiasis: This is also not considered a sexually transmitted disease. It results from an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly due to altered vaginal flora. Treatment of the male partner is not required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Treatment of the male partner is essential in cases of trichomoniasis to prevent reinfection and break the cycle of transmission.

questions.text: In a patient with Wilson's disease, which of the following is decreased in urine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 3-methylhistidine

 

3-methylhistidine is decreased in urine in Wilson's disease. This decrease is associated with the abnormal buildup of copper in the liver, leading to decreased excretion of 3-methylhistidine in the urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosine: Tyrosine levels may not be significantly affected in Wilson's disease. The primary concern in this condition is related to copper metabolism rather than amino acids like tyrosine.

 

Option B. Phosphorous: Phosphorus levels are typically not significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The main diagnostic markers for this disorder are related to copper levels.

 

Option C. Serine: Serine levels may not be significantly altered in Wilson's disease. The primary metabolic disturbance in this condition is related to copper accumulation rather than amino acids like serine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's hepatolenticular degeneration is an inherited autosomal recessive condition.

 

  • The basic defect is a mutation in a gene encoding a copper binding ATPase in cells, which is required for excretion of copper from cells. So, copper is not excreted through bile, and hence copper toxicity.
  • Increased copper content in hepatocyte inhibits the incorporation of copper to apo-ceruloplasmin. So ceruloplasmin level in blood is decreased.
  • Clinical Features
    • Accumulation in liver leads to hepatocellular degeneration and cirrhosis.
    • Deposits in brain basal ganglia leads to lenticular degeneration and neurological symptoms.
    • Copper deposits as green or golden pigmented ring around cornea; this is called Kayser-Fleischer ring.
  • Treatment consists of a diet containing low copper and injection of D-penicillamine, which excretes copper through urine. Since zinc decreases copper absorption, zinc is useful in therapy.
  • Amino acids are excreted in the urine in either conjugated (mostly) or in free form. The amount of conjugated amino acids in urine is far more than free form in Wilson’s disease. Methyl Histidine largely exists in free form and does not increase in amount on hydrolysis of acids in urine, hence the urinary levels of 3-methylhistidine are low in patients with Wilson disease.

choices.text: Human papilloma virus
Herpes simplex virus
Human immunodeficiency virus

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human papilloma virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Benign vulval warts are caused by HPV-6 and 11 (low risk HPV types)

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes AIDS, which leads to immunosuppression and various opportunistic infections.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a member of the herpesvirus family and can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not cause vulval warts.

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Benign vulval warts (condyloma acuminata) are caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A woman at 30 weeks of gestation is diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Which of the following is the most appropriate for this patient for prophylaxis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

 

During pregnancy, the choice of anticoagulant therapy is crucial due to the risks associated with both the mother and the developing fetus. Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the drug of choice for anticoagulation in pregnancy across all trimesters. It is preferred because it does not cross the placenta, making it safe for the fetus, and it has a lower risk of causing bleeding complications compared to other anticoagulants.

 

In this specific case of a woman at 30 weeks of gestation diagnosed with DVT, LMWH is the most appropriate choice for prophylaxis. Warfarin, although sometimes used in the second trimester, is generally avoided due to its teratogenic effects, particularly during the first trimester and closer to delivery.

 

Newer anticoagulants like Apixaban and Fondaparinux are not typically recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient evidence of safety and potential risks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Warfarin: Warfarin can be used during the second trimester up to 36 weeks if necessary. However, it is typically avoided in pregnancy because it crosses the placenta and can cause fetal complications, especially if used in the first trimester or near term.

 

Option C. Apixaban: Apixaban, a newer oral anticoagulant, is generally avoided in pregnancy due to a lack of sufficient data supporting its safety for the fetus.

 

Option D. Fondaparinux: Although Fondaparinux has a lower risk of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), it is not the first-line choice during pregnancy. The data on its safety in pregnancy are limited, and therefore, LMWH is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the preferred anticoagulant for both the treatment and prophylaxis of DVT during pregnancy across all trimesters due to its safety profile for both the mother and fetus.

choices.text: Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg HS for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam 500 mcg one tablet OD for 7 days
Tablet alprazolam ½ mg tablet HS daily

questions.text: As an Indian medical intern, which of the following is the correct format for prescription of alprazolam? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tablet alprazolam 0.5 mg once a day before bedtime for 7 days

 

IMPORTANT POINTS REGARDING PRESCRIPTION WRITING:

 

  • Prescription is invalid without date and signature of the doctor.
  • Drug name should never been written in abbreviation form (e.g. never write PCM for paracetamol).
  • Abbreviations like OD, BD, HS etc should not be used in prescription.
  • Leading zeros should always be mentioned (e.g. 0.5 mg is correct but .5 mg is incorrect)
  • Trail zeros should never be written (e.g. 5 mg is correct but 5.0 is incorrect).
  • Microgram should be written as mcg not as µg.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When writing a prescription, always avoid abbreviations for dosage instructions, use clear and complete language, include leading zeros for dosages less than one, and avoid trailing zeros. The correct format ensures clarity and safety for the patient.

questions.text: The farmer presents with a cauliflower-like mass on the foot, which developed after a minor injury, as depicted in the image. Microscopic examination reveals the presence of copper penny bodies. Based on this information, what is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chromoblastomycosis

 

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is chromoblastomycosis.

 

Chromoblastomycosis:

 

  • Causative Organism:  Fonsecaea, Cladophialophora species.
  • Clinical features: The initial presentation consists of warty papules that gradually enlarge, forming a hypertrophic plaque resembling cauliflower. Over the course of months to years, these lesions progress to large, hyperkeratotic masses with a surface often speckled with black dots.

 

 

Histopathology: Foreign body granuloma & Sclerotic / Medlar / Copper penny /Muriform bodies.

 

Treatment: Itraconazole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Blastomycosis:

  • Caused by the fungus Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • It primarily affects the lungs but can spread to other parts of the body, including the skin.
  • Skin manifestations can be ulcerative or verrucous but the presence of "copper penny bodies" is not a characteristic feature of this infection.
  • Thus, the microscopic finding does not match this option.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis/Rose Gardeners disease.

Few important points about Sporotrichosis:

  • Caused by Sporothrix schenckii
  • An acute or chronic fungal infection where, a linear distribution of nodules is seen Commonly in gardeners, florists due to high thorn prick possibility.

 

Clinically presents with Linear noduloulcerative lesions (Sporotrichoid) aligned along lymphatics, with Satellite lesions.

 

Sporotrichoid lesions also seen in

 

  • FISH TANK/SWIMMING POOL GRANULOMA
  • LUPUS VULGARIS.

 

The given images show the distribution of lesions along lymphatics.

 

 

Histopathology:  Asteroid bodies are seen.


Treatment: Itraconazole / Terbinafine / Saturated solution of Potassium Iodide.

 

Option D. Phaeohyphomycosis:

  • Represents a group of infections caused by various dematiaceous fungi.
  • Lesions can vary in appearance from nodules to cysts or abscesses.
  • Unlike chromoblastomycosis, phaeohyphomycosis does not characteristically have sclerotic or "copper penny" bodies under the microscope.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromoblastomycosis is identified by its clinical presentation of verrucous skin lesions and the histopathological finding of sclerotic or copper penny bodies, indicative of infection with dematiaceous fungi.

questions.text: A patient had wheezing and shortness of breath. His PFT revealed FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value. What is the likely diagnosis in this patient?(FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Asthma

 

Explanation:

 

The key findings in this case are wheezing, shortness of breath, and pulmonary function test (PFT) results indicating an obstructive lung pattern (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value). These findings strongly suggest that the patient is suffering from asthma.

 

Asthma is a chronic inflammatory condition of the airways characterized by bronchial hyperresponsiveness, airway obstruction, and symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness. The PFT results showing a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio and reduced FEV1 are consistent with the obstructive airway pattern seen in asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial lung disease: This group of disorders primarily affects the interstitium (the tissue between the air sacs) and is not typically associated with wheezing or an obstructive pattern on PFT.

 

Option C. Pneumoconiosis: This refers to lung diseases caused by the inhalation of mineral dust or fibers, such as coal worker's pneumoconiosis or asbestosis. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is not typically associated with wheezing or an obstructive pattern on PFT.

 

Option D. Bronchiectasis: This condition is characterized by irreversible dilation and destruction of the bronchi, leading to chronic cough and copious sputum production. While it can cause shortness of breath, wheezing is not a common symptom, and the PFT pattern may vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with wheezing, shortness of breath, and PFT results indicating an obstructive pattern (FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7 and FEV1 <80% predicted value), asthma should be strongly considered as the likely diagnosis.

 

Obstructive Vs Restrictive Lung disorders:

questions.text: What is the smallest diameter of the true pelvis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sacrocotyloid diameter

 

The sacrocotyloid diameter measures 9.5 cm (3¾") and represents the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the iliopubic eminence. This is the smallest diameter among the major pelvic measurements in the true pelvis. It holds particular clinical significance as it represents the space occupied by the biparietal diameter of the fetal head while negotiating the pelvic brim in cases of flat pelvis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interspinous diameter: The interspinous (or bispinous) diameter measures 10.5 cm and extends between the tips of the two ischial spines. While this is an important diameter at the midpelvis and represents the narrowest part of the pelvic cavity, it is still larger than the sacrocotyloid diameter.

 

Option B. Diagonal conjugate: The diagonal conjugate measures 12 cm (4¾") and extends from the lower border of the symphysis pubis to the midpoint of the sacral promontory. This is significantly larger than the sacrocotyloid diameter and is measured clinically during pelvic assessment.

 

Option C. True conjugate: The true conjugate (also called anatomical conjugate) measures 11 cm (4¼") and extends from the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of the symphysis pubis. Though important, it is not the smallest pelvic diameter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sacrocotyloid diameter (9.5 cm) is the smallest of the major pelvic measurements and has clinical significance in obstetrics as it may limit fetal head passage through the pelvic inlet, particularly in cases of flat pelvis.

choices.text: Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic
Surgical repair on the next elective list
Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel

questions.text: An asymptomatic patient presents with a reducible hernia below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following is the most appropriate management to consider? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Surgical repair on the next elective list

 

Explanation:

 

A femoral hernia occurs below the inguinal ligament through the femoral ring. While this patient's hernia is currently asymptomatic and reducible, femoral hernias have rigid boundaries (femoral vein laterally, inguinal ligament superiorly, pubic arc inferiorly, and lacunar ligament medially), creating a high risk for strangulation. Femoral hernias warrant prompt elective surgical intervention regardless of symptoms, as they have a significantly higher risk of complications compared to other hernias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Watchful waiting and follow-up if symptomatic - Incorrect because femoral hernias have a significantly higher risk of strangulation (approximately 50% present as emergencies). Unlike some inguinal hernias, femoral hernias should not be managed conservatively, even when asymptomatic.

 

Option C. Emergency surgical repair of hernia - Incorrect because the hernia is currently reducible and asymptomatic, not requiring immediate emergency surgery. Emergency surgery is indicated for irreducible, obstructed, or strangulated hernias.

 

Option D. Emergency surgical repair with exploration of the bowel - Incorrect for the same reason as option C. Additionally, bowel exploration would only be necessary if strangulation was suspected, which isn't the case in this reducible, asymptomatic hernia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

All femoral hernias should be repaired surgically on an elective basis due to their high risk of strangulation, even when asymptomatic and reducible.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the hospital with complaints of fever, rash and swelling of her hands and feet since past 5 days. There is desquamative skin rash, edema of hands and feet, erythema of palms and soles, oral erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the likely condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kawasaki disease

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Kawasaki disease or mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome.

 

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness associated with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It is commonly seen in infants and children <4 years of age.

 

KAWASAKI DISEASE MNEMONIC

 

CRASH & Burn

 

  • Conjunctivitis (non-purulent)
  • Rash
  • Adenopathy (cervical and commonly unilateral)
  • Strawberry tongue
  • Hands (palmar erythema/ swelling)
  • Burn (fever lasting at least 5 days or more)

 

The disease is usually self-limiting. In some cases, the disease may involve coronary artery leading to thrombosis and acute myocardial infarction.

 

Rx: Intravenous immunoglobulin and aspirin may be given to reduce the risk of coronary artery disease.

 

Other Options:

 

 

Option D. Henoch-Schönlein purpura is an acute, systemic, immune complex-mediated, leukocytoclastic vasculitis. It is characterized by a clinical triad of palpable purpura (without thrombocytopenia), abdominal pain, and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kawasaki disease is characterized by a persistent fever, erythematous and polymorphous rash, edema of hands and feet, strawberry tongue, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It primarily affects children under 4 years old and can lead to serious coronary artery complications if not treated appropriately.

questions.text: Which among the following options describes the chest X-ray image? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coeur en sabot

 

Chest X-ray image describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

 

 

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot ("Coeur-en sabot").
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Egg on side appearance: Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great arteries (TGA)

 

Option C. Egg on string appearance: Scimitar sign is seen in Scimitar syndrome which is also known as partial anomalous pulmonary venous return.

 

Option D. Snowman sign: Snowman sign is seen in supracardiac TAPVC

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart on a chest X-ray is characteristic of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), which results from right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to the distinctive cardiac silhouette.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: Which of the following binds to tyrosine kinase receptors?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Insulin

 

Option B. Insulin: Insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors known as insulin receptors (IR). When insulin binds to these receptors, it activates the tyrosine kinase activity of the receptor, resulting in the autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues and the initiation of intracellular signaling cascades. Therefore, insulin binds to tyrosine kinase receptors.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. LH (Luteinizing Hormone): LH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. LH binds to its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (LH receptor) on the surface of target cells, leading to the activation of intracellular signaling pathways via G proteins.

 

Option C. TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone): TSH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. TSH binds to the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR), which belongs to the family of G-protein-coupled receptors. Activation of TSHR leads to intracellular signaling through G proteins, not tyrosine kinase activation.

 

Option D. TRH (Thyrotropin-Releasing Hormone): TRH does not directly bind to tyrosine kinase receptors. It acts on its specific G-protein-coupled receptor (TRH receptor) to initiate signaling pathways through G proteins, similar to TSH.

 

Educational objective:

 

The insulin and IGF-I receptors have intrinsic ligand-activated tyrosine kinase activity. By binding to these receptors, these hormones will activate tyrosine kinases inside the cell which in turn phosphorylates important enzymes for involved in a number of processes such as metabolism, growth and differentiation and also inflammatory response.

 

Ref- Harper 31st ed./pg – 508

choices.text: Inferior vena cava
Right atrium
Superior vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation

 

  • Inferior vena cava has the highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation.
  • Fetal heart pumps large quantity of blood into the placenta for exchange of substances.
  • From placenta, the umbilical veins collect the blood, which has more oxygen and nutrients.
  • Umbilical vein passes through liver, some amount of blood is supplied to liver from umbilical vein, large quantity of blood is diverted from umbilical vein into the inferior vena cava through ductus venosus.
  • Liver receives blood from portal vein also.
  • In liver, the oxygenated blood mixes slightly with deoxygenated blood and enters the right atrium via inferior vena cava.
  • From right atrium, major portion of blood is diverted into left atrium via foramen ovale. Foramen ovale is an opening in intra-atrial septum.
  • Blood from upper part of the body enters the right atrium through superior vena cava. From right atrium, blood enters right ventricle.
  • Then, blood is pumped into pulmonary artery. From pulmonary artery, blood enters the systemic aorta through ductus arteriosus.
  • Only a small quantity of blood is supplied to fetal lungs. Blood from left ventricle is pumped into aorta.
  • Fifty percent of blood from aorta reaches the placenta through umbilical arteries.

 

 

Mixing potentially occurs at 4 sites:

 

  1. Left umbilical vein (Oxygen saturation ~80%) – Portal vein (Much bypassed by ductus venosus to Inferior Vena cava)
  2. Left umbilical vein – Inferior vena cava – Portal vein (Oxygen saturation of IVC blood is ~65%)
  3. Superior vena cava – Right atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale)
  4. Pulmonary veins – Left atrium (Much bypassed by Foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right atrium: Incorrect. While the right atrium receives blood from the inferior vena cava, it also receives deoxygenated blood from the superior vena cava, leading to a mixture that has a lower oxygen concentration than the incoming blood from the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Superior vena cava: Incorrect. The superior vena cava carries deoxygenated blood from the head and upper limbs of the fetus, thus having a lower oxygen concentration.

 

Option D. Ascending aorta: Incorrect. Although the ascending aorta in the fetus does carry oxygenated blood, the highest concentration of oxygen is found in the blood before it reaches the heart, specifically in the inferior vena cava due to the direct input from the umbilical vein through the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The highest oxygen concentration in fetal circulation is found in the inferior vena cava due to its receipt of oxygen-rich blood from the umbilical vein, which has directly exchanged gases in the placenta. This setup is crucial for delivering a sufficient oxygen supply to the developing fetus.
